item.description:
A card game of city building. The game uses a custom deck of cards. Each card represents one building. Each building has five traits: color, type, size, class, and age.

The players score points by constructing complimentary buildings next to one another. The number of points scored for placing (constructing) a building depends on how many traits it has in common with the immediate neighbor. This ranges from -5 points for zero common traits to 16 points for four traits in common.

"The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck and all possible cards have been played. Winning: The player with the most points at the end of the game wins."

item.description:
A city building board game.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. The playing pieces consist of a set of 24 Zone counters in a different color for each player and a set of 16 Landmark counters. Each Landmark is marked with a Prestige Point value and each Zone counter is marked with an Access Point value.

The Landmarks are randomly placed on the board. The players then take turn placing Zone counters until all the spaces on the board are filled or no player can place a Zone counter. Control of Landmarks is then determined. The player controlling the Landmarks having the highest total Prestige Points wins the game.

"A strategic 2-player simulatiion of naval combat in the Napoleanic era."

The game is played on an 8x8 grid. A chess board may be used. Each player has a set of eight Ship tiles. Ships are divided into four classes, numbered 1 to 4. Ship Class determines attack range, hull strength, and number of masts. Each ship is also rated for six skill types, described as follows in the rules: Seamanship, Gunnery, Command Authority/Discipline, Morale/Courage/Health/Stamina, Marksmanship/Snipers/Muskets, and Boarding/Swashbuckling/Hand-to-Hand Combat/Marines/Crew Size.

"Victory: The player with the most captured ships at the end of the game wins. If tied the player who sunk the most ships wins. The game ends when there are no ships left to capture or sink."

"Long Ago in the Land of Faerie there was a war between the Sprites and the Pixies. Board & card wargame for 2 players. One player is the Pixies and the other is the Sprites. Each figure represents a single faerie (unit)."

The game is played on a chess board or grid. There are eight different types of terrain: Clearing, Thorns, Water, Great Oak, Thick Growth, Magic Circle, Aerial Roots, and Forest.

Chits or miniatures to represent faeries. Each side has four types of units: King, Mage, Knight, and Warriors. Each unit type is rated for hit points, magic, melee, ranged attack, and poison. The players share a custom deck of cards. Card play is used to determine when units can move, defend, and attack.

"Victory: You win if you kill the opposing King."

Choose to play one of nineteen famous, or infamous, captains - ranging from Sinbad the Sailor to Admiral Horatio to Blackbeard to Jack Sparrow. Each captain has a named ship, crew type, starting port, and special ability that provides an advantage in the game.

The game is played on a circular track divided into twenty-four spaces. Every third space is a port or other special space. All other spaces are open sea.

The object of the game is to find the hidden Pirate Chest and return it to your starting port. To find the Chest you must first gain possession of the Hidden Map and Hidden Key.

"Card game for 2-4+ players. Each player is one of Santa’s Elves helping to make toys for Christmas. The Elf who makes the most Toys by games end wins. Game End: The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck, and all player’s hands are empty. Victory: The player with the most points worth of cards in his Toy pile at the End of the game wins."

"2-4+ player board & card wargame. Each player controls an Advanced Spacefaring Alien Civilization."

Each Alien Race sends its fleets out to conquer the galaxy. Each Race has six attributes which can change throughout the game: Attack, Defense, Movement, Production, Strategic, and Initiative.

The players share a custom card deck containing two types of cards: Technology and Event. Technology cards give a Race a new ability or an attribute bonus that last for the duration of the game. Event cards represent temporary bonuses and effects.

The game is played on a hex map of space filled with ten "terrain" types: Alien Ruins, Star Cluster, Nebula, Super Nova, Black Hole, Dark Matter, Quasar, Worm Hole, Asteroid Field, and Deep Space. Each type of space has a special effect, except for Deep Space which has no effect.

There are two ways to win the game. Either control all the Star Cluster spaces in play or occupy the most spaces when the deck runs out.

"Card game for 2 players. Theme: WWII Eastern Front Battle of Stalingrad. One player is the Soviets. The other player is the Germans."

Each player uses a unique deck of cards. There are five suits marked 1 through 10 in each deck. The German suits are Firepower, Objectives, Morale, Tactics, and Forces. The Soviet suits are Defense, Locations, Morale, Tactics, and Forces. The cards depict elements of the historical campaign.

The players attempt to play the highest ranking card combination each hand. "Victory: The German Player must win 3 Hands in a row (Ignore Ties) to win. If the German player has not accomplished this by turn 10 the Soviet player wins."

item.description:
"Card game for 2-6+ players. Fantasy World Setting. King Jaspar the Just is Dying. Only one of his 12 sons can ascend to the Throne. This can only mean that 11 sons must first die."

"Each player is betting on up to 4 of the 12 Brothers to win the Crown. The 4 Brothers that a player is betting on are his Favorites."

"Victory: If one of your Favorites is the last left alive, you win. More than one player can win. It is also possible that all players lose."

"China 475 – 221 BCE. Each player is the king of one of 7 States vying for domination. Card game for 2-7 players."

There are three custom card decks used in the game - the Event Deck, Resource Deck, and Battle Deck. The Resource Deck consists of cards which can be exchanged in combos to raise taxes (Agriculture, Mines, and Cities.) The Resource Deck also contains cards for several types of Generals (Daring, Steadfast, Brilliant, Methodical, and Thoughtful.)

The Battle Deck consists of Strategy and Troop Cards. When battles are fought, the other players may choose to add cards to support the attacker or defender.

"Victory: The first player to control 15 Province Tokens wins the game."

"Card game for 2-4+ players. Wonder Woman Theme."

The game is played using a custom card deck. There are ten suits in the deck: Wonder Woman, Ally, Capture, Foe, Info, Plot, Quote, Item, Action, Minion.

"The most feminist player goes first."

The players score points by playing melds of four to ten cards, each of which must come from a different suit.

"Victory: Have the most points when the deck runs out."

"Individual Soldier Combat in the world of Ogre/G.E.V."

"Mobile Infantry Soldiers fight as cohesive, Battle suit wearing squads. They combine firepower and area defense measures making them the most effective combat formation in mankinds' long history of warfare. The six-man squad is the norm: 1 Paladin-suit for command and control, 1 Commando-suit for targeting enemy forces and spoofing the enemy’s sensors, and 4 Marauder-suits are the basis of the squad’s firepower."

"Card game for 2 players. The action takes place in the world of Virtual World of Tron."

One player represents Tron and the other plays as the Master Control Program or MCP. Each player uses a separate custom deck of cards.

The Tron deck is made up of six types of cards: Programs (Characters), Skill (used to defeat Games and Security), Escape (used to go Rogue), Activation (used to become Activated), Transport (used to reach the Mesa), and Sub-Routines (various effects).

The MCP deck has four types of cards: Control (required to win the game), Games (used to destroy Programs on the Game Grid), Security (used to destroy Programs off the Game Grid), and Sub-Routines (various effects).

The MCP player wins when all ten Control cards have been downloaded (put into play). Tron wins by Derezzing (destroying) the MCP in Program Delete Phase.

item.description:
A game of full scale war on the planet Mongo. Set in the Flash Gordon universe.

One side controls the forces of Human Hero Flash and his allies, Hawkman Chieftain Voltan and Forest Chieftain Baron. The other player controls the forces of Evil Emperor Ming. Each unit is rated for the following statistics: type, move, initiative, attack, defense, cost, and area of recruitment.

The game is played on a map depicting a major continent on the planet Mongo. There are five regions in the continent. At the start of the game, the Central and Southern regions are under Ming's control while the North, East, and West regions are controlled by the forces of Flash. The regions are further divided into territories, some of which represent Major Cities and some of which are impassable mountains.

The Flash player wins if Ming is killed. Ming wins by killing all of the Rebel Leaders.

"Rebel troops are attacking Ming’s Palace. Who will carry the day?"

The Rebel forces under the leadership of "Human Hero Flash" are closing in on the palace of the Evil Emperor Ming, ruler of the planet Mongo.

The game is played on a hex map showing the area around Ming's Palace, which is located at the center of the mapsheet. All of the Imperial units start within two hexes of the palace and the Rebel forces start along the map edges.

The Rebels win if Ming is killed. The Imperials win if all of the Rebel Leaders are killed.

"The game spans over several rounds. Every round each player selects one of the five different roles which will determine a certain action for all players. The player who manages to build the most powerful civilization at the end of the game will be the Lord of Ancient Times."

"Winning the Game: The winner will be the player with most Victory Points at the end of the game." Victory Points are earned by founding cities, discovering advancements, and building wonders.

The designer credits San Juan as the inspiration for this print-and-play civilization building card game.

item.description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Gwen Stacy was Peter Parker’s true love. In order to jack up the sales of their funny books Marvel decided it was a good idea to kill her off. Sales did go up, as did fan outrage. Now heres a chance to redo comic book history but with a twist."

The game uses a custom deck of 52 cards. There are five types of cards: Method, Conspiracy, Location, Save, and Fate.

The players attempt to play melds of cards of the same type. 
A player who is unable to play a meld on a turn must roll on the Event table and take the specified action. Once you have three melds in play (one each for Method, Conspiracy, and Location), you may make a die roll to see if you kill Gwen Stacy. If the roll is successful you win the game, otherwise you lose some or all of your melds and the game continues.

"Players control Pirate ships in search of plunder & adventure. Victory: The first player to accumulate 100 Gold is the winner."

Players move their ships around a circular ring of 48 spaces. The starting space is Port Royal, a safe zone. The other spaces consist of areas at sea or merchant ships. Merchant ships can be plundered for goods, which are exchanged for gold in port. Certain spaces cause turns to be lost, others call for a card draw.

The players face warships, weather, and other hardships. Players can also battle one another when they land on the same space, which can lead to a boarding action.

"Players are Stone Age Tribes. Players create and trade objects of value. Victory: The first player with 50 Victory Points is the winner."

The game is played with a custom deck of cards made up of six suits: Weapons, Tools, Food & Textiles, Containers, Jewelry, and Statuettes.

The players score points by playing melds. There are two types of melds, Kits and Hoards. A Kit is a meld of six cards with one card from each suit. A Hoard is a meld of five cards from one suit.

item.description:
"A solo card and dice game of trading in the Imperium."

"In this one player game you play the Captain and crew of the FREE TRADER BEOWULF. The Goal is to profit 73 Mega Credits (i.e., 73,000,000 Credits), which is just enough to buy a SUBSIDIZED LINER and become a Merchant Prince. But in the 1350th year of the GALACTIC EMPIRE, this great Utopian civilization of Humanity is far from civilized. Trading in the Spinward Marches Sector, even close to its ducal capital REGINA, can still be dangerous."

Expansion rules allow the game to continue as a Master Trader with a Subsidized Liner attempting to earn another 73 Mega-Credits to build a Mercantile Principality.

In Nice Weather, you and a million tourists travel around Europe chasing, that's right, Nice Weather. Spend your autumns and winters around the Mediterranean, your summers by the Baltic coast and your springs in Central Europe.

Travel by your own railroads or pay the other players to use theirs. Set your ticket prices high to squeeze out profits or low to undercut competitors. If you can't find a cheap train ticket, then you can always go by airplane, in which case you might contribute to global warming. Global warming makes the Southernmost cities unattractive, while new holiday destinations pop up in the far North.

Will you bet on a bright future and invest in ferry lines to the sunny islands of the South? Or will you defy the icy emptiness of the North and then keep prices high to make people fly and tilt the climate in your favor?

Nice Weather is a relatively fast and family-friendly track building game with a foundation of logical thinking paired with prisoner's dilemma-like pricing diplomacy and livened up by random action cards that lets you set hilarious traps. But amidst the easy and fun, the experienced player will inhale a strong breeze of Go as the network struggle scatters among a dozen frontiers that suddenly merge to one final whole, making the player with the most well-oiled micro-macro mental elevator the winner.

Dynamic land prices let you buy up cheap competing lines, allowing for a randomized yet balanced game board; for each game, 6-12 European cities out of 28 are randomly selected, making for up to 36000 different start configurations. Then there is always Essen, and this is where you start the game; in October 2008 to be exact.

item.description:
"Card Game for 2+ players. Star Trek theme." The game is played with two custom card decks - the Crew Deck and the Dilemma Deck.

The Crew Deck cards represent crew members, actions and equipment. They are used to solve Dilemmas. Cards have ratings for one or more of the following attributes: Tactics, Science and Negotiation.

The Dilemma Deck cards represent episodes from the first season of Star Trek. Each card lists what levels in the three attributes are needed to solve the Dilemma. Each card also has a Victory Point value.

"Game Ending: The game ends when all Dilemmas have been solved. Victory: The player with the most Victory Points (from solved Dilemmas in his Captains Log) is the winner."

"A battle between Futuristic Troops."

Each side has sixteen units: eight Troopers, two Tanks, two Aircraft, two Hovercraft, one Artillery, and one Commander. The object of the game is to kill the opposing Commander.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Actually a SPIN and Move game. The box says that this game is "The Pot Party Game of Crazy Dares and Hilarious Surprises" The object of the game is to go from the Start to Munchies Land using spin results from a "Do or Dare Spinner". The game box stated that this game is "for fun and is not meant to be played for marijuana. The game pokes fun at those that smoke weed. The game comes with a 12 x 7 game board, a die, a Do a Doobie Dare spinner, 6 game markers and a rule book.

item.description:
This is a (relatively) straightforward card battle game that includes a pun (or two). The "fighter" cards that battle are futuristic spaceships called "Multi-dimension Attack Ships" (M*A*S), yeah, you can say "mass." There are cards that destroy an opponent's M*A*S. That card is called, of course, a "Weapon of M*A*S Destruction" (we warned you).

That is a very powerful card, so before you are allowed to play it, you must announce it. If opponent has a Search card, he gets to search some of your cards to try to find it and remove it. The search card is called, of course, a "Search for Weapon of M*A*S Destruction" card. Cute.

The search mechanics are interesting. Players play to win battles and gain Respect Points. When you find Weapons of M*A*S Destruction, you might gain respect (depending on which search card you have). When you don't find Weapons of M*A*S Destruction (depending on the card) you could "lose all your Respect." (ok, no more puns).

Players take turns attacking, choosing between 3 types of attacks. Each card has a "weak spot" on it. During one phase of the game players try to name the weak spot of opponent's M*A*S -- If they do it is destroyed. (These "shots" at opponent's cards are called "long shots"). Battles are usually "2 on 2" with extra "destroy" and "search" cards. Cards are awarded to each player based on rules, mostly "who won the attack?"

There is a Draw Phase, a "Deploy & Destroy phase" a "Long Shot" Phase, and an
"Attack" Phase. After the Draw Phase, each of the 3 remaing phases provides 
interesting and different types of action. (See 'more info' below).

2 to 6 players, best with 2 to 5 singles or teams of 2 or 3. 64 cards + instructions.

"Solo Science Fiction Card game with two decks. You control the Mega Tank trying to wipe out the defenders more conventional forces."

The Mega Tank Deck contains cards representing the weapons, defenses, and other aspects of the Mega Tank. The Defence Force Deck contains the numerous units which are opposing the Mega Tank: infantry, bombers, tanks, guns, etc.

If the Mega Tank loses its 40 armor points, each additional point of damage causes a card to be removed from the Mega Tank Deck. If the Mega Tank Deck runs out of cards, the tank is destroyed and the player loses. If all of the Defender cards are discarded to the Casualty Pile before the Mega Tank is destroyed, the player wins.

A game apparently inspired by Ogre.

item.description:
Gridstones is an elegant, gripping game of strategy and visualization.

Designed by Toronto native Tim W. K. Brown, this critically-acclaimed abstract strategy and puzzle game is quick, fun, easy-to-learn and great for the whole family.

Simply place or remove STONES on or from the GRID to create a match to the cards in your hand - but be careful, your opponents will be trying to match their cards too, and the grid will change with every turn.

So if you’re up to the challenge, grab a friend, or six, and get hooked on this engaging, strategic game of pattern matching.

Grid size versus number of players:

 4x4 grid - 2 Players
 5x5 grid - 3 or 4 Players
 6x6 grid - 5 or more players

item.description:
"Board & card game for 1-5+ players. Pedestrian Glass Bead Game Variant."

The game is played on a 10x10 grid with spaces large enough to contain a single game card. The deck contains over 100 cards specifying historical persons, events, things, places and ideas. Each card has one of fourteen special abilities, such as "draw 2 cards", "place an extra card this turn", or "steal one random card from opponent's hand."

Points are scored by placing cards next to cards with common characteristics. The game ends when the board is completely filled up. The player with the most points wins.

(from GMT website:)

Crown of Roses is a 3-hour block game set during the turbulent years of the Wars of the Roses in 15th Century England. This 35-year long conflict saw the extinction of a large number of noble houses, and would eventually set the house of Tudor upon the throne.

In Crown of Roses, players take on the roles of the dynastic giants - the House of Lancaster and their Beaufort cousins, and the House of York. The four player game adds in the powerful House of Stafford, and the ever-scheming Richard Neville and his son, Richard of Warwick, the 'Kingmaker'.

Using intuitive mechanics, Crown of Roses offers players a historical feeling with tremendous strategic depth and excellent replayability. Unit starting locations vary with each turn and even with each game, and the use of blocks creates the "fog of war" of limited intelligence on enemy strength and deployment. Random game events throw a touch of the chaos of the era into the mix, and the multiple uses for the player action cards leads to a level of uncertainty where enemy plans are concerned.

During each game turn in Crown of Roses, players will play cards to perform actions such as improving their armies, influencing the locals to support them, collecting supplies or prestige, moving to attack enemy forces, to recruit new houses to your cause, calling another Royal Heir into the fray, or even changing the nature of the conflict through the use of player events.

Unit blocks rotate to show strength, and each army can have a variety of experience levels and combat capabilities. A novel roll to hit-based system is used to determine combat results, with better experienced forces scoring hits more often in battle. Kill all of the enemy heirs, and you can rule England unimpeded!

In Parliament, players can try to gain a favorable posting or take control of the crown itself by gathering enough noble support. Gather enough votes for enough years and the nobles of parliament will welcome you as their sovereign!

And if you can create enough influence with the local gentry, your economic might will sway the common folk to support you as their chosen monarch!

And the four player game of Crown of Roses allows all of this and more without the sacrifice of the unique fog of war aspect that the unit blocks provide. With each player having up to three ways to win, who knows who will be the next King of England!"

TIME SCALE Variable

MAP SCALE Area Movement

UNIT SCALE Noble houses and mercenary factions

NUMBER OF PLAYERS Two to Four

DEVELOPERS: Andy Young and Kevin Bernatz
ART DIRECTOR/PACKAGING: Rodger B. MacGowan
MAP ART: Knut Grünitz
CARD & COUNTER ART: Charles Kibler

name.value: Wings of War: Fire from the Sky

item.description:
The WW2 series of Wings of War is an easy, fun to play, fast and furious system which previous fans of the game will be able to start playing minutes after opening the box! New game mechanics support a simulation which must encompass planes with very different flight capabilities and firepower, while still keeping the flow of the combat simple as it is in the WW1 series. The innovations to maneuver cards and to the fire deck system provide all the needed historical accuracy with no headaches to the players!

“Fire from the Sky” is the second set in the new series of Wings of War games, which will allow you to re-create dogfights, bombing missions, escorts, and endless other aerial combat situations set in World War Two. New fighters are introduced into the system, among which the Curtiss P-40 Tomahawk featured in several allied color schemes including the famed Flying Tigers. Airacobra, Yak 1, Reggiane Re.2001 Falco II, Hien and several other fighters from every WWII front are also included. The newest add to the system are Anti-Aircraft guns in ground nests and three different dive bombers: Stuka for the Axis, Val for Japan and Dauntless for United States and France.
Up to 6 planes can fly with the contents of this set, for scenarios with 1 to 6 players.

Part of the Wings of War series

Expanded By:

 Wings of War: The Dawn of World War II
 Wings of War: Flying Legend Squadron Pack
 Wings of War: Eagles of the Reich Squadron Pack

item.description:
From the box: "An educational and fun trivia-type game of railroad facts, history & modeling."

The six knowledge categories on each card are: People and Times, Engineering, Hobos and Slanguage, Railroadiana, Model Railroading and Caboose[appears to be general train knowledge].

Default game is to nine correct answers but the rules mention you can set the endgame to any number you like.

The cards are color coded so they can be used with other trivia-type games [example: you could replace the Trivial Pursuit deck with this deck].

The questions are not easy.

SnowCrystals is a beautiful and challenging pattern game. The game contains 96 diamond shaped tiles with segments from five different snow crystals printed on them. The goal of the game is combine and match the pieces to form completed snow crystals. SnowCrystals is appealing to adults as well as Ages 5 and up.

The snow crystal designs were patterned after the photographs of snowflakes in the historic book SnowCrystals by W.A. Bentley and W.J. Humphreys, Dover Publications - New York, 1962.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get his BMX bike completely over the FINISH line, having got there by luck and skill in the use of Race Cards and dice.
The game board is enhance by "dirt" ramps (jumps and berms), and the playing pieces are actual little BMX bikes.

Army of Ireland is a tactical level recreation of the historically significant Battle of Ridgeway, where encroaching Fenians clashed with spirited Canadian militia in what is now Ontario.

From the publisher:

In the period immediately following the American Civil War, a group of Irish-Americans known as the Fenians conceived of a bold plan that they hoped would result in freedom for Ireland. A volunteer army, comprised mainly of hardened Civil War veterans, was established for the purpose of an invasion of Canada. The Fenians reasoned that territory seized from British controlled Canada could be bartered for Irish independence. Army of Ireland is a tactical level recreation of the historically significant Battle of Ridgeway, where encroaching Fenians clashed with spirited Canadian militia in what is now Ontario. Colorful counters, a detailed hexmap, and other components provide everything needed to re-fight this conflict which was to have a profound influence on Canadian history.

This is a very primitive copy of Monopoly from Burma (Myanmar).
It was purchased at a Burmese market in about 1990. As in all monopoly sets, the streets are named differently, but the play is the same. In Burmese Monopoly, all of the streets are named after cities and towns in the country of Burma.

"Each player takes the role of a Heart Patient. Object: Be the patient to live the longest."

The game uses a custom deck of cards consisting of six types: Medical Interventions, Lifestyle Modifications, Surgery, Pathological Events, Drug Therapies, and Heart Attack Cards.

Each player rolls up a character/patient to establish seventeen "risk factors", which include items such as Family History, Cholesterol Levels (LDL, HDL, and Total), Weight, Diabetes, Alcohol, and Smoking.

A card game which takes its theme from the universe of the science-fiction film Heavy Metal.

The game uses a custom deck of cards. There are five types of cards in the deck: Hero (Heroine), Foe, Location, Travel, and Special Cards.

The first player to make five melds wins the game. A meld consists of one Hero/Heroine card, two Foe cards, two Location cards, a Travel card, and a Special card.

"Simple World War I Naval Combat rules. Map, counters, and dice game." Played on a hex map showing sea and land hexes.

Scale: The rules specify that each hex is 600 feet across (one Nautical mile = 10 hexes), each round is one minute, and each counter is one ship.

The players alternate moving one ship at a time. The players may have any of their ships fire some or all of their guns at any time. A gun battery can only be fired once per turn. When all ships have moved once, the round ends.

Statistics, including unit costs, are included for over twenty ships and submarines of the British and German fleets, as well as for shore batteries and mine fields. The rules cover factors such as anti-submarine warfare, aircraft, aircraft carriers, hidden u-boat movement, and torpedoes.

"Wargame for 2 or more players. Fantasy Northern theme. Victory: Destroy all enemy units."

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. Map tiles are randomly distributed in the center 49 squares, the border squares being considered sea spaces. The terrain tiles come in eight different types: tundra, glacier, water, villages, forest, mountains, peaks, and hills.

Each player starts with one Hero unit placed on a Village tile. The players must recruit units and build armies. Units that may be recruited include Norsemen, Barbarians, Viking Ships, Northern Dwarves, White Dragons, Frost Giants, Polar Bears, Ice Witches, and Yetis. A deck of Spell Cards is used to determine the capabilities of units that have magical powers. Players can augment their forces with relics (Magic Axe, Druid's Staff, or Banner) which increase the power of certain units.

"Card game for 2+ players. Based on the novel 'Naked Lunch' by William S. Burroughs. Each player is a 'junkie writer' living in the Interzone. The Interzone is a fantasy underworld city of addiction, intrigue, drugs, monsters, homosexuality, hedonism, control, humor, despair, and violence. Writers compete to be the first to finish their book."

"Game play: Writers convert Junk (drug) cards into pages (of their book). Writers make contacts (Junkies, Doctors, Monsters, etc) that they can use to attack (& defend themselves from) their opponents."

"Victory: The first player to write 213 (or more) pages wins."

"Card Game for 2 players. One player gets the Shark Deck. The other player gets the Shark Hunter Deck. The Hunters have a fishing boat. The boat has 5 Hull points. There are 5 people in the boat. The shark has 10 life points."

"Winning: A game of survival - if all five people are eaten, the Shark player wins. If the Shark is reduced to zero life points the Hunter player wins."

Abstract fantasy warfare game. The object is to destroy, capture, or control all of your opponent's pieces.

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. Each player has a set of sixteen pieces, two each of eight types: Knave, Beauty, Royalty, Knight, Sorcerer, Monster, Army, and Castle.

A six-sided die is rolled to determine movement points. These points can be split among one or more units, with each a movement point being expended for each square entered. Cards are used to make attacks. Each card may only be used by one type of unit.

"You are a Barbarian Warrior surrounded by enemies. Kill them all before they kill you. Solo card game."

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are three kinds of cards in the deck - Attacker, Defense, and Kill Cards. Each turn the player chooses to draw one to three cards. Defense and Kill cards are kept in the player's hand (up to a maximum of six), and Attacker cards are placed face up on the table. Each Attacker in play at the end of the turn causes one point of damage to the player (up to a maximum of four points per turn).

"You have 10 hit points. If you are reduced to zero Hit points you lose."

"If you go through the whole deck without dying you win (You have escaped). Your score is equal to the number of hits you have left plus the number of attackers you killed."

"Card game for 2+ players. Roman Emperor theme. Players compete for the chance to be Emperor. The most Decadent player wins."

"Each player is either the Emperor or a Plebeian. Only one player at a time can be the Emperor At the beginning of the game all players start out as Plebeian."

The game uses a custom card deck containing numerous subdivided classes of cards, the two main categories being Assassinations and Bread & Circuses. Other cards types include Political Support, Military Support, Intrigue, Soldiers, Reputation, Private Entertainments, Public Entertainments, Orgies, Tortures, Arena Games, and Decrees.

The game board is a circular track divided into twelve spaces. Two cards are placed on each space and the players collect cards as they move around the track. The players score points based on the cards they hold, certain cards scoring points for Plebians and other cards scoring points for the Emperor.

"Victory: The player with the highest Score at the end of 7 turns wins."

"Card game for 2-4 players. Each player is a faction of the Knights Templar. Players try to build the best Legacy for the Templars possible. The game ends when one player has 5 or more Downfall cards, or when there are no more cards in the deck."

The game uses a custom deck composed of nine types of cards: Legacy, Allies, County, Treasures, Mission, Power, Battles, Enemies, and Downfall. Collecting certain types of cards provides Victory Points. The winner is the player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game.

"Board & Dice game for 2 players. Based on the Fantasy Film Krull. One player is the Good Prince Colwyn. The other player is the Evil Beast in his teleporting Black Fortress."

The game is played on a circular track divided into thirty-two spaces. Every fourth square is a Village. Each player has one pawn. The Colwyn player's pawn represents Prince Colwyn and his Companions, numbering ten men at start. The Beast player's pawn represents the Beast in the Black Fortress.

The Beast wins by razing all eight Villages or by killing the Prince. The Prince wins by locating the Black Fortress, killing the Beast, and saving Princess Lyssa.

"Card Game for 2+ players. Each player represents an incarnation of Lawrence of Arabia. Players recruit Arab allies and use them to attack the Turks. Victory: The first player to have Mission cards in his Victory pile with a total Force Rating of 40 or more wins."

The game uses a custom deck of cards. There are five types of cards in the deck: Events, Leaders, Tribesmen, Missions, Defenses. The players put Leader cards into play in order to recruit Tribesmen. Leaders and Tribesmen are assigned to complete missions on Mission Cards. Defense cards are played against other players. Each time a Leader and his band are used for a mission, there is a chance they may disband and be removed from the player's control after the mission has been completed.

"Sci-Fi Themed Card game. Lunar Warfare between 3 main Factions."

"The Lunarians live underground and were not even aware of the Humans presence. Likewise the Humans did not know about the Lunarians. When the Silexians arrived, in a single colony ship, they immediately detected and Proceeded to Attack the colonies of both other races. All sides have been openly hostile to each other in the ensuing confusion & carnage."

The Lunarians start with six Bases each having a Force value of six, the Humans with four Bases each having a Force value of four, and the Silexians with two Bases each having a Force value of five. Each player uses a unique deck of Unit, Event, and Modifier cards which are used to launch attacks and to defend Bases.

The object of the game is to eliminate all of the enemy Bases.

"Players represent ideologies in conflict in the 20th century."

The players select one Ideology to play: Democracy, Communism, Fascism, Socialism, or Imperialism. If there are more than five players, five additional Ideologies are available: Totalitarianism, Parliamentarian, Dictatorship, Monarchy, and Fundamentalism.

The game is played on a map of the world divided into twenty regions. The components also include a custom deck of cards, consisting of Conflict Cards and Influence Cards.

"Object: Control the most countries by the end of the century. Ties are resolved by bidding. Each round represents 5 years. The game starts in 1900 and ends in 2000. There are 20 game rounds."

"Help He-Man defeat Evil Skeletor and his Minions."

"One player uses a Good Deck. The other player uses an Evil Deck. Each deck has 2 discard piles: A Reserve pile and a Casualty pile."

"Object: A player loses when all of his Leader cards are in his Casualty pile. The other player wins the game."

"Megazilla attacks Tokyo!!!!!!! One player is Megazilla, the other is the Japanese military trying to defend the city."

The game is played on a map of Tokyo divided into "blocks." The blocks come in three types: Water, City, and Rural. The Megazilla player has one counter representing Megazilla. The JDF player has 80 counters representing land, air, and sea units of the Defense Force. Other counters include Rubble and Artillery Attack. The components also include a custom deck of cards used by the Megazilla player.

"Victory: The JDF (Japanese Defense Force) wins if Megazilla is ever at 75 or more points of damage. Megazilla wins if he makes it to the opposite end of the map and reduces at least half of the city blocks to rubble."

"WWI card game for 2 players. Recreate the last great cavalry campaign in history. One player is the British. The other player is the Turks."

Each player uses a custom card deck composed of the following types of cards: Cavalry, Infantry, Artillery, Planes, Machine Guns, Supply, Leader, and Nuisance Cards. Battles are resolved in a series of phases: Air Strike, Cavalry Exploitation, Artillery, Machine Gun, and Infantry. The player who wins each battle scores a Victory Point.

"Victory: The British win with 5 Victory points. This indicates that they have overrun the Turks, and that they have captured Damascus before their Arab allies led by Colonel Thomas Edward Lawrence, also known as Lawrence of Arabia. The Turks win with 3 Victory points. This indicates that the Turks have made a successful fighting withdrawal and that they have retreated back to Turkey without being overrun."
A French party word game in which players try to identify words related to a theme on the cards. The title of the game is a pun on the "baccalauréat" examination.

item.description:
A collectible card game based on football players from the English Premier League.
In 2009, a German edition with players from the Bundesliga was released.

The aim of a game is to form a team of 14 (11 starting players and 3 substitutes), and to score more goals than your opponent by comparing attack or defense values on each player card.

Special cards include "Star Player" cards and "Man of the Match" cards.

Set firmly in Greek legend, Blood and Bronze mixes roleplaying and boardgaming aspects to make competitive and strategic 1-2 hour game. Each player acts as one of the cities of Greek legend using alliances, treachery, accusations and boasts all feature as the cities strive to be remembered as the greatest in all of Greece. To win the game strive to become dominate, called "Without Peer!" in 3 of four arenas: Army, Hero, King and God. If by the end of the agreed playing time no player has won, then the Game is said to have been won by those upstart Romans.

This game is described by the publisher as "much more a boardgame kind of thing than a role-playing game." Others have tried using the term "resource management game" to avoid both the board and RPG labels. It is available in both regular edition, with cardboard chits, and the Without Peer! edition that has bronze coins and a brass bowl.

The original version of the game was an entry in the 2005 Iron Game Chef RPG Game design competition This version is still a hybrid game but more towards the role-playing end of the spectrum than the final product.

Game description from the publisher:

In Comédia, you'll imagine skits, mime words, play characters, and read scripts – alone, in pairs or in teams. Release your inner thespian, dress up however you like and play out of your skin! At any age, with friends or family, Comédia is a board game which will let your imagination run riot and which is also a perfect team-building educational tool for theater workshops, professional seminars, etc.

Alles auf Angriff is a soccer card game about "Die Wilden Fußballkerle". They are the main characters of a famous soccer book series for children.

The player tries to get 5 cards at first: 4 player cards and 1 trainer card.

The player can display one player card, get one card from an opponent or start an offense in order to get one player card from the opponent.

Luck and bluffing will pave the way to success.

item.description:
This dice game is a derivative of The Game of Life. It contains a dice bowl, a score pad and 10 dice.

The aim is to get as many Life Points at the end of the game as possible. You throw the dice up to three times each turn. If you collect the symbols you need for a life experience, you win Life Points.

The Game of Life Express is part of the Hasbro Express Line.

item.description:
Play six different card games while learning unique horse facts and vocabulary from each card.

Build a corral of cards before the mustangs escape in the solitaire game Stop the Stampede! Make rows of cards using higher and lower numbers in Rising Trot. Win cards to spell HORSE in Have You Herd? Collect sets of cards in Roundup and Colorful Horses, but avoid the lone mustang in Old Mare.

This versatile card deck also includes four bonus collectible horse breed cards.

Tien Gow, along with Pai Gow is one of the most popular games played with Chinese Dominoes.

Tien Gow is a four-player trick-taking game in which each of the dominoes has a specific value when played either as singletons or in combinations against other dominoes. The value of each set of tiles is based on the standard, idiosyncratic ranking of Chinese dominoes, an order that often does not correlate with the numerical value of the tile. Players unable to beat the high set during a trick must discard an equivalent amount of tiles face down. Points are awarded during the round, for special plays, and at the end, based on the number of tiles won by each player. Score multipliers may also apply, depending on the endgame conditions. Like Poker, it is typically played as a gambling game using chips.

item.description:
A book on the campaigns of Alexander with detailed information on pay scales, organization, logistics and march rates to help the miniature gamer recreate an accurate tabletop campaign.

" This book includes what is probably the most detailed and accurate account of Alexander as a military commander so far published as well as all the information on march rates, logistics, pay, loot, sieges, armament, organisation and other related factors required by wargamers.

It describes the troops of Alexander's own armies and their opponents, their tactics and weapons and how these altered to meet changing circumstances. As well as being a tremedously exciting and stimulating read, the book is thus an essential reference source, at once of immense value to Ancient wargamers and food for thought to serious historians." (from the dustjacket)

name.value: Sea battles in miniature. A guide to Naval Wargaming.

item.description:
A comprehensive guide to Naval Wargaming with miniatures,covering ancient galley warfare, Napoleonic naval battles,the Ironclad period and the Dreadnought period. As well as providing and excellent potted summary of each period, there are simple and playable rules for each era.

"The chance to be an Admiral in command of some of the finest fleets in the history of naval warfare is not one which many me could resist. Here, at last, is a book which will not only enable you to reconstruct battles with great historical accuracy, but also to take charge of the fleets and shape the destiny of nations! The pages almost reek with the smell of powder and ring with the clmour of battle."

Contains chapters on:

-Naval wargaming in General, including building your own models and writing rules.
-Ancient galley warfare
-Napoleonic nval warfare.
-The Ironclad period.
-The Dreadnought period.
-Campaigns.

name.value: A Wargamers' Guide to the Crusades

item.description:
A concise and detailed account of the Crusades for the miniature wargamer. The book not only covers the background history, but provides background detail on the various military orders, the Assassins and the raising and financing of troops. Finally a detailed gazette of crusader castles rounds out the book.

160 pages with numerous maps and line drawings.
Preppy Life. Roll and move your way to getting schooled, getting drunk, getting privilege, and getting a trust fund from Mummy and Daddy.

Steaming sex or a passionate romance...

The Romeo and Juliet love tube is the fast track to romance and adventure, in the unlimited universe of sexual fantasy. It’s time to see how far you and your partner can take the pleasure principle. Romeo+Juliet is a game with intimate questions and lust arousing chores for two. The winner can expect extravagant indulgence, the loser can look forward to glorious punishment...

1 game board
1 book of questions and chores
1 book of romantic and adventurous punishments
2 counters
1 twenty sided love dice
1 rulebook
1 bag

The game is played on a castle's foundation (a square grid) where players place their pieces of different colors, trying to get the largest groupings of their color together. As they play, players also lay walls and doors, as well as "room tiles", which determine the shape and size of each room in the castle.

item.description:
2 de Mayo is an abstract game of the terrible incidents that took place in Madrid on May 2, 1808. On that date, civilians in Madrid — and a few Spanish army units — rebelled against the French occupation troops of Napoleon.

2 de Mayo is a bilingual (English and Spanish) boardgame for two players, in which each player controls the forces of one side, either Spanish or French. The game lasts 10 turns and takes about 20-30 minutes to play.
Each turn is divided into four phases:

 Preparation
 Orders
 Movement
 Resolution




At the end of Turn 10, the French player achieves victory if all the Spanish forces have been eliminated, all the access areas to Madrid are French garrisoned and has not lost four or more cubes. If a French victory does not apply, the Spanish player wins.

The game includes:

 board showing the old map of Madrid, divided in 21 areas or zones
 41 wooden cubes: 30 blue (representing the French troops), 10 red (representing the Spanish civilians and troops), and 1 unpainted used as the turn marker.
 22 event cards, 11 French (blue back); and 11 Spanish (red back)
 2 player aid cards
 1 turn track card
 rulebook, including historical commentaries and a full example of play

item.description:
[EN] Strength, balance, bravery and good sense. These are the four key words for the castellers. In this game you will have to use all of them to emulate the brave castellers and to raise the higher towers of the game.


 Components: 66 castellers wooden pieces in 4 colours, 2 sets of stickers, 12 pinya base tiles, 2 bonus tokens, 1 bag, a set of rules.
 Game has rules in English, Spanish, Catalan and Portuguese.



[ES] Fuerza, equilibrio, valor y sensatez. Estas son las cuatro palabras clave de los castellers. En este juego tendrás que usarlas todas para emular a los valientes castellers y levantar los castells más altos de la partida.


 Componentes: 66 castellers de madera de 4 colores, 2 conjuntos de adhesivos, 12 baldosas base de la pinya, 2 fichas de bonus, 1 bolsa, reglas.
 El juego dispone de reglas en inglés, castellano, catalán y portugués.



[PT] Força, equilibrio, valor e sensatez. Estas são as quatro palavras chave dos castellers. Neste jogo terás que usá-las todas para simular os valentes castellers e levantar os castells mais altos da partida.


 Componentes: 66 castellers de madeira em 4 cores, 2 conjuntos de autocolantes, 12 bases de pinya, 2 fichas de bónus, 1 bolsa, regras.
 O jogo vem com regras em inglês, castelhano, catalão e português.



[CA] Força, equilibri, valor i seny. Aquestes són les quatre paraules clau dels castellers. En aquest joc hauràs d'emprar-les totes per tal d'emular als valents castellers i aixecar els castells més alts de la partida.


 Components: 66 castellers de fusta de 4 colors, 2 conjunts d'adhesius, 12 rajoles base de la pinya, 2 fitxes de bonus, 1 bossa, regles.
 El joc disposa de regles en anglès, castellà, català i portuguès.

item.description: Game about Austrian offensive from August 1914. Over 400,000 soldiers from both sides (Austro-Hungarian and Russian) fought in fierce battle near KraÅ›nik (now in Poland) on 23-35 September. In the battle, a decisive role was played by manoeuvre and the power of artillery.

A telephone dial points to the brightly coloured picture which the child may "discard" if he happens to have the same picture in front of him. The child uses the dial to turn the colours indicated by the 2 dice he has thrown. If the arrow on the dial points to a picture that corresponds to a picture which the child has in front of him on the table, the child may turn it over. The first player to succeed in turning over the pre-determined number of cards is the winner. The game consists of a telephone dial, 72 cards and 2 colored dice.

The White Squadron is a set-building card game similar to the children's game "Fish" or "Go Fish."

The 52 cards in the deck depict warships of the U.S. Navy around the turn of the century. It was evidently printed in many editions because at least one copy seems to date from about 1919 based on the ships depicted, even though the original copyright date is 1896.

The ships are divided into "fleets" of four similar ships, mostly historical class sister ships ranking from "A" through "M" with each ship in the fleet numbered from "1" though "4."

For example, the "A" fleet comprises the battleships Oklahoma, Nevada, New York and Texas. The "M" fleet comprises the submarines Plunger, Porpoise, Shark and Moccasin.

Each card lists its identifying number "A-1, M-4"; the name of the ship in larger type with the sister ships in smaller type; a photograph or drawing of the ship and a three-line description.

For example, the Plunger's description reads: "PLUNGER -- Submarine torpedo boat. Holland type, operated by gasoline when in the surface and electricuty when submerged. 63 feet long. Has 3 14-inch Whitehead torpedoes for sub-sea attack."

The object of the game is to collect "fleets" of four cards with the winner being the player with the most "fleets" at the end of play.

Five cards are dealt to each player with the surplus forming a common draw pile.

The player to the dealer's left begins by asking any one player for a specific card . For example, "Do you have H-3 Massachusetts?" If the player has the card he must give it to the caller, who can then ask for another card from anyone around the table.

If the targeted player doesn't have the card, then the caller must draw one card from the draw pile and play passes to the left.

Once four cards in the same fleet are collected the player paces them down on the table face up.

If a player has no cards then he is entitled to draw two cards from the draw pile.

Once the draw pile is exhausted, play continues with the cards in hand only until all the fleets are formed.

The rules don't say, but presumably players who have no cards and can't draw from the draw pile can still continue to play and acquire cards for a fleet, although they would be vulnerable to poaching from other players.

This game almost mirrors that of Balderdash, but was published about 9 years prior. The game play is the same in that one player reads a word and the others try to fake out everyone by writing down a fictional definition. Points are awarded when others pick yours as the correct definition.

This may be one of the first packagings of the old Dictionary Game.

This is an Australian 62-card deck with 5 suits of 12 cards. The suits are Waves (green), Hearts (red), Diamonds (yellow), Clubs (blue), and Spades (black). Each suit contains 12 cards - Ace, Woman, Man, 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, and 2. The jokers have been replaced by a Pope and a President card. The deck comes with a leaflet that has rules for the games of Waves (aka Black Pete), Estate Bridge, 600, Pusoy Dos, Poker, Canasta, and Euchre. It can easily be used to play other card games like Solitaire, Snap, Crazy 8s and Rummy.

Radpi'Sushi is a real time card game for 2 players.
Each player is a famous restaurant server of
RAPID'SUSHI.

This restaurant has become famous thanks to the speed of service:
fifteen customers is indeed served in less than 2 minutes.

With this reputation, customers are already queuing in front of the restaurant with their Sushi command.

It's up to you to serve sushi tables faster than your opponent and win the round of the day..

After one week of work, the boss will display the winner of the week in the famous restaurant.

This was first do it yourself game and now the game is available on the edition world.

International Elite S.W.A.T. the Boardgame (tentative name)

S.W.A.T. the boardgame is a strategic, tactical police simulation game based on modern weapons and technology for 1 to 6 players. Play with pre-made characters or create your own character from scratch and watch your character rise through the ranks. Players may use weapons in accordance with their style of play ranging from assault rifles to sniper rifles that are fully customizable with various scopes, suppressors, and sights.
 
Play 3 different maps:
- The Bank: Small Map 
- The Plane: Medium Map 
- The Mansion Estate: Large Map

Play with 6 different weapons:
- Assault Rifles 
- Submachine Guns 
- Light Machine Guns 
- Shotguns 
- Sniper Rifles 
- Sidearm Pistols

Complete your arsenal with numerous supplementary weapons:
- Grenades
- Smoke Grenades
- Thermal Goggles
- Gas Masks
- Various Suppressors
- Various Gun Scopes
- Various Tactical Sights
- Armor Piercing Bullets
- Tear Gas
- Breaching Charges

Players read through a Mission Booklet and decide which of the missions to perform. Terrorists are set up and players set up on their starting locations. Each mission will have an objective and a secondary objective for those playing with Career Mode Characters.

Types of Missions:
 - Hostage rescue
 - Escort the V.I.P.
 - Retrieve and escape
 - Double assassination
 - Protect control points
 - and many more

item.description:
Chaos on Cronos is Pulp Sci-Fi miniatures rules from Scott Pyle of Four-Color Figures. These rules use Scott's Goalsystem.

From the author:
"Rocket into the far future with Chaos on Cronos, the Goalsystem tabletop miniature game of Pulp Science Fiction! Chaos on Cronos is a skirmish game designed for heroic scale 28mm miniatures, and uses designs and characters from Blue Moon Manufacturing's excellent line of Spacemen and Aliens. Cronos works great with as few as 5 figures per side, and using the GoalsystemÊ¼s innovative Robot Legion rules, can accommodate as many as 20-30 figures per side! All you need to play are these rules, a handful of six-sided dice, and some Blue Moon miniatures! Cronos also features complete model creation rules so you can stat up your favorite Pulp sci-fi heroes, villains, and soldiers for battle!"

Available in PDF.

The Trioker pieces are similar to the 24 mac-mahon triangles, except that the values are set at the corners instead of the sides. There is also a 25th special triangle, called Joker

There are two boards allowing two different kind of games : a pure abstract game for 2 players, and a bidding game for 2 to 3 players. Also included a set of puzzles to be solved for a single player.

At first sight, Trioker looks very much like Tri-Ominos, but in fact it is a much more complex game, with lots of logic involved.

name.value: Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory

item.description:
From the DG website:

Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory (NEW), aka Glory, has been moved back to new status due to an exciting development. The designer has added two new elements to the game that will make this a truly unique ACW game. First, he is adding Manifest Destiny, a Mexican-American War mini-game that will serve as an introductory scenario. This short campaign will give new players an excellent place to start playing and veteran players will have a game that can be finished in an evening. The second element is Crisis & Compromise, a card play oriented game of the period from the end of the Mexican-American War to the start of the Civil War. Though little combat occurs (guerrilla warfare in Kansas, etc.), the card play covers the actions inspiring events, leaders and regional positions (Border States) that affect the allegiance of states to a region and the ability of military leaders at the start of the Civil War. Crisis & Compromise can be played alone or used to create alternative starting situations for Glory.

Glory is a grand strategy game of the American Civil War in the style of Krieg! Maps of the Eastern and Western Theaters include terrain, Strategic Objectives, roads/rail, naval zones, navigable and non-navigable rivers, cities and locales, supply centers and other features affecting the game. Counters represent the corps and armies of the war. Cards provide the strategic-political-economic direction for each side. Strategies are many and varied but the ultimate goal is to demoralize the opposing faction's population through military, economic and political victories while sustaining your own population's will to continue the fight. The players each choose a Strategy Card and an Addendum Card before each new season and may opt to play an additional card as a diplomatic response to certain events. These cards lead to new military units, leaders, and replacement steps and result in socio-economic and political events. The events include the declaration of Emancipation, the elections of 1862 and 1864, and the possible intervention by European nations. Events are often double-edged swords, sometimes providing a military advantage while negatively affecting the popular will to fight. In addition, both sides may attempt to develop and manufacture new technologies, both historical and speculative, such as ironclads, submarines, torpedoes, observation balloons, repeating rifles and Gatling guns. Both sides can introduce espionage and even sabotage, which can have many unexpected consequences, including assassination. Three maps, 352 large counters for Glory and 280 small counters for Manifest Destiny and Crisis & Compromise, 220 cards.

name.value: Clubhouse: the tee to green golf game

item.description: Players play their way through the Druid's Forest golf course using 3 coloured dice to determine the results of each golf shot. Distance is determined by a book of "Club Cards" showing the results of each die combination for each club chosen. The game is played on 2 large boards showing the 2 halves of the course. Scorecards and player markers are included.

"The Strategy Game of Common Cents"

This two-player game was inspired by Nim - the popular game, played with piles of objects, that was invented by mathematician Charles Bouton in 1902. It appeared in the October, 1995 issue of Games Magazine, and requires 49 pennies (or other small objects).

The game is played on a 7x7 board filled with one penny per square, although each player removes one penny of their choice at the beginning of the game. Game play consists of players alternating turns of removing two or three adjacent pennies from the same horizontal or vertical row. The last player to be able to remove such a group wins.

As stated in the box: " El país legendario del vampiro se halla en el Este de Europa, especialmente en Rumania. Allí se encuentra, en la provincia de Transilvania, el lugar que el autor británico Bram Stoker eligió para su famosa historia de Drácula.

La historia se remonta a la Edad Media, donde un cauidillo llamado Vlad Tapes, que significa 'Vlad el empalador', tenía el sangriento hábito de empalar a sus enemigos en estacas y beber su sangre, de ahí su similitud con Drácula.

Cuenta la leyenda que toda persona mordidad por un vampiro se convierte en vampiro. Sólo hay una forma de acabar con él: clavándole una estaca en el corazón'

Drácula (El vampiro del castillo) es un juego de terror para jugadores de 9 a 90 años, en el que pueden participar de 2 a 4 jugadores.


Translation: "The legendary country of the vampire exists on Eastern Europe, exactly in Romania. There is the province of Transylvania, place that inspired the British author Bram Stoker to create his famous Dracula.

The story starts on the middle ages, where a local Lord called Vlad Tapes, meaning 'Vlad the Impaler', had the bloody habit of impaling his enemies and drinking their blood, from there the similarities with Dracula.

The legend tells that anybody bitten by a vampire will become a vampire. There is only one way to finish it, that is by nailing a stake through its heart".

Dracula is a game of terror for players Ages 9 and up, and for 2 to 4 players.


The game comes with:

- A board game
- 24 vampires
- 24 plastic bases

item.description:
This game appeared in the June, 1996 issue of Games Magazine. It requires tokens, which are not included.

Players slide their tokens along the board, attempting to score points by getting them all along a line. First player to three points wins.

Players push a six-sided die from adjacent sides of a 4x4 grid in an attempt to complete loops that extend both horizontally and vertically. In the basic game, one player has access only to the left and right sides, while the other has access exclusively to the top and bottom sides.

The author designed with the game with the same Celtic knot picture cubes used in Osbo, but this game doesn't make use of rotating the sides. The same face of the die stays visible once the die is entered.

Trugo is a board-less tile-laying game with Go-like capture. It has a "Waxing" phase, in which tiles and chips are added, and a "Waning" phase, in which chips are moved or tiles are removed to capture the chips they touch.

Trugo can be played with 36 Mambo tiles (plus 2 colors of chips, 25 each) by treating red and blue segments as equivalent.

Take the Raiders™ to the top!

Play Jenga® a fun new way – with Oakland Raiders blocks and Raiders dice that add excitement to the game! It’s the same great game with a Raiders twist. Build your tower with Raiders black and gray blocks. As the tower builds so does the difficulty. Custom Raiders Jenga rules make the game even more challenging and fun! Roll the dice and make the play… “Touchdown” reverses the direction of play; “Interception” allows you to remove one black and one gray block and the “Raiders Shield” means you pick another player to remove and stack any block. The last player to remove a block without tumbling the tower wins the game.

Take the Steelers™ to the top!

Play Jenga® a fun new way – with Pittsburgh Steelers blocks and Steelers dice that add excitement to the game! It’s the same great game with a Steelers twist. Build your tower with Steelers black and yellow blocks. As the tower builds so does the difficulty. Custom Steelers Jenga rules make the game even more challenging and fun! Roll the dice and make the play… “Run” means you remove a yellow block; “INT” allows you to remove one black and one yellow block while the “Steelers Logo” means you get to skip your turn. The last player to remove a block without tumbling the tower wins the game.

The MOON MULLINS Game based on the comic strip of the same name. The comedic things that happen in the cartoon strip happen in this game from "Bumping in to a Fat Lady" which causes you to move back 2 spaces to "Tripping over Carpets" which results in your being able to advance 3 spaces. This is a simple roll and move game from the late 1930's.

Components for 1927 ed:
16.25 x 16.5" non-character specific game board
5 die-cut thin cardboard full-color character playing pieces
4-1/8 x 4-1/8" separate spinner with large image of "Kayo!" 
set of character playing cards

This game appeared in the August, 1996 issue of Games Magazine. It can be played on any flat surface, and requires cards, dominoes, coins, or any other objects that can be arranged in rows and columns.

Each player starts with "campers" in a grid-like "campsite." Players take turns moving campers from their opponent's campsite into their own, according to rules inspired by the "Game of Life" mathematical simulation by John Horton Conway. When no more moves are possible, each player scores points based on the campers in his or her campsite. In the simplest version, most campers wins.

"Race to the moon and back as the United States of America and the Soviet Union compete for International prestige. The game starts in the late 1950's and spans 3 decades. It attempts to simulate the economy, the military, and the scientific community as they play crucial roles in the race to the moon. This is only a game but the events contained herein are real. You'll experience the frustrations of failure and the joys of success as we take you back in time into the Great Space Race."

The game board depicts a track 30 spaces long. The object is to be the first player to get to the moon (space 30) and return back to Earth (space 1). The game also uses a deck of Launch Cards broken down into three groups reflecting events of the fifties, sixties, and seventies.

Bashni is a traditional Russian game in the Checkers family.

The game is identical to Shashki (Russian Checkers) in the rules regarding movement, capture, and promotion, but every time a piece is captured, it is put at the bottom of the capturing piece or stack. If the captured piece is itself on a stack, only the top piece is captured, and the underlying pieces are thus "liberated". This means pieces are never permanently removed, but stacks get steadily higher throughout the game.

According to Abstract Games magazine issue 1, the game has a revival in Russia, with tournaments being held in St. Petersburg regularly.

Bashni was the inspiration for Laska, Chess world champion Emanuel Lasker's stacking game, that is better known in the west.

item.description:
Texas Hold'em Poker with Dreidels!

Players get a couple of dreidels in the hole (not seen by other players) and together with a three more communal dreidels bet chocolate gelt against the other players that they have the best 5-dreidel combination.

The standard edition is for 2 to 4 players, but the deluxe edition has enough dreidels for 8 players.

Home Page: http://www.texasdreidel.com/index.php

item.description:
Title: Man Hunt, by Parker Brothers, circa 1937.

The following information is summarized from the game rules.

"""The Idea of The Game"""

Each player is an agent in pursuit of a criminal. By means of clues furnished on the cards and in the envelopes you may, by the use of a little judgment, be the first to catch your criminal and earn the major portion of the reward. For two to six players.

"""Equipment"""

1 Game board - An outline map of the United States, showing the names of states, cities, and routes of travel that must be used when traveling from one city or state to another.

6 Different colored Pins- Used to represent each player.

24 Biographical cards- Each showing a sketch and biographical information on a separate criminal.

A few examples of biographical cards include a few BLACK AMERICANA cards:

"LUCKY" HAMES, WANTED for holdup and robbery in Jackson, Miss., on April 5, 1936. Age 31, Height 5 ft. 7 inches. Weight 136 lbs. Eyes maroon, complexion black. Hair usually close cut. If arrested notify police at Jackson, Miss.

"WHITEY" COLLINS, WANTED for murder of white man in Dallas, Texas, on February 8, 1934. Age 33, Colored, Height 5 feet 7 inches. Weight 155 lbs. Hair black and kinky, eyes maroon, complexion full black. If arrested notify Police Department of Dallas, Texas.

"TOMBSTONE" THOMPSON, WANTED for hold-up and robbery of a woman in Abilene, Texas, on Sept. 30, 1936. Age 31, Height 5 feet 9 inches; Weight 165 lbs. Very prominent front teeth---one gold. Typical field hand, close cropped hair. Scar under right eye. If arrested communicate with Police, Abilene, Texas.

"MIDNIGHT" JOHNSON, WANTED in Atlanta, Georgia, for slashing another negro with razor, in fight over crap game, Dec. 31, 1936. Age 31, Height 5 feet 7 inches, Weight 145 lbs., Sporty dresser, black, short, fairly straight hair. Scar on nose. Hold and notify Atlanta Police.

24 Envelopes bearing each criminals name - Each envelope contains either four or five clues to assist in tracking the criminal and trace his movements.

2 dice - Used to determine player movement.

160 Bills - Paper money in denominations of $100, $50, $20, and $10.

"""To Start"""

Each player is given $1000.00 and puts $500.00 into a pool which is set aside to serve as reward money. Players then randomly choose a criminal to track. Opposing players then are provided the clue envelopes for their opponent's criminal. Players then place their pin on the map where their criminal is wanted. Highest roll of the dice goes first.

"""The Play"""

Players then attempt to track their criminal first by reading the biographical card, and judging what location the next clue to his whereabouts may be obtained. Dice are then rolled to determine the distance the player can move, the full amount of two dice for air travel, the large number of the two for express train, or the smaller number of the two dice for automobile. Upon arrival at his destination he will ask the player holding his clue envelope if a clue is found at the location. If no clue is found he must return to the city he started from, or last city where he obtained a clue. Players may also send other players on missions to uncover clues for them. If the player being sent refuses the mission he must pay $100 into the reward pool. If he goes on the mission and uncovers a clue for another player he will receive $50 from that player. If no clue is uncovered, the player sending him on the mission pays $50 to the reward pool.

The final clue will advise of the death or capture of the criminal.The first player to uncover all of the clues for his criminal receives $1000, the second to finish $800, and third $600, and any players after $500, or until the reward pool money is exhausted. The player with the most reward money at the end is the winner.

Based on the popular game Time's Up!, Time's Up: Title Recall challenges players to guess the titles of books, films, songs, and more. Players try to get other players to guess the same set of titles over three rounds. In each round, one member of a team tries to get his teammates to guess as many titles as possible in 30 seconds. In round 1, almost any kind of clue is allowed. In round 2 no more than one word can be used in each clue (but unlimited sounds and gestures are permitted.) In round 3, no words are allowed at all.

item.description:
Translated from publisher's description:
The small Eskimo child Enuk is already completely excited. Today he may go with his large brothers on journey into the ice. Finally he may see the wild polar bears on their way, watch the seals fishing and fish himself through the ice holes. At most, however, he looks forward to building the igloo with the others. However, the day goes on much too fast...

The children have to build the igloo and to observe as many animals as possible at the same time. Who collects most animal tiles and builds the igloo successfully, will win!

Description of the mechanics:
Enuk is a mixture of memory and push-your-luck. Players turn over animal tiles, until they want to quit or one of the animals is scared and flees: the herring flee from the salmon, salmon flees from the seal, the seal flees from the polar bear and the polar bear flees from the Eskimo. How many tiles dare you turn over?

item.description:
Originally an ancient Hindu game for children, Pulijudam is a two player strategy game free from elements of chance. It is almost an abstract strategy game, but one of its alternative names, "Lambs and Tigers", suggests the theme overlaid for children.

Pulijudam is very similar to Bagh Chal and Fox and Geese - it is essentially a member of the Hnefatafl family of asymmetrical abstract games, although of very different origin. One player uses three pieces representing tigers; the other player uses fifteen pieces representing lambs. The initial placement of the three tigers is fixed. The lamb player begins to place his fifteen lambs wherever they wish in the twenty remaining spaces on the board; neither side can move any pieces until all of that type have been placed. Therefore the tigers may begin to move from the third turn while the lambs may only move from the fifteenth turn.

Each piece may move to any vacant adjacent space on the board (effectively orthogonally). Tigers may 'eat' lambs by jumping over an adjacent lamb into a vacant space beyond.

The game is won when the tigers have captured all the lambs or the lambs have encircled the tigers preventing them from moving.

item.description:
Subject : This game covers the fourth battle for Tsaritsyn, from June, 12th to July, 1st 1919. Wrangel's cavalry Army of the Caucasus attacks the fortified area of the Red Verdun. With infantry and tanks reinforcements, coupled with sudden appearance of Mamontov's cavalry corps manoeuvring on the rears, the Whites manage to take the city at the end of June.
The Reds benefit from special advantages such as Budyenny's cavalry corps, river flotillas and trenches.

Scale : regiments or brigades. 1 hex = 4 km. 1 turn = 1 day

English or French versions available. 20 pages booklet (rules and historical article), a player aid and 306 full-colour counters. The map is 42*60 cm (about 16*24 inches).
The counters have to be cut and mounted (high quality Desk Top Game).

booklet contents : 
- Rules : 9 pages 
- Examples : 1p 
- three scenarios : 3p 
- historical notes : 3p (and maps) 
- author's notes and play notes : 1p

Scenarios : 
- introductory scenario 
- scenario in 4 turns : the last days of the battle 
- the full battle
